{{for|the state university system|State University System of Florida}} {{pp-semi|small=yes}} {{Use mdy dates|date=September 2011}} {{Infobox university |name = Florida State University |image_name = FSU_seal.svg |motto =''Vires, artes, mores'' ([[Latin]]) |mottoeng =Strength, Skill, Character |established =1851{{#tag:ref|Florida State University currently fixes its date of establishment to 1851, the year the Florida legislature voted to establish two seminaries of learning: West Florida Seminary (which became the Florida State University) and East Florida Seminary (which became the [[University of Florida]]).{{Cite web| title=Timeline | work=The Florida Memory Project | publisher=State Library and Archives of Florida | year=1851 | url=http://www.floridamemory.com/exhibits/timeline/index.cfm | accessdate=July 9, 2010}} West Florida Seminary used this date of establishment prior to 1905, when the Buckman Act reorganized higher education in Florida and the three resulting state institutions all adopted 1905 as their founding date. In 1935 the [[Florida Board of Control]] changed the founding dates of the University of Florida and the Florida State College for Women (now Florida State University) to the years their predecessor Seminaries opened as state-sponsored institutions, and Florida State's founding date was changed to 1857. In 2000 the Florida State University declared 1851 to be its official founding date.{{cite news |title= FSU's age change: history or one-upmanship?|first=Barry |last= Klein|newspaper=[[St. Petersburg Times]]|date= July 29, 2000 |url= http://www.sptimes.com/News/072900/State/FSU_s_age_change__his.shtml|accessdate=July 9, 2010}}|group=note}} |type =[[Flagship#University campuses|Flagship]] [[State university system|state university]]
[[Sea-grant university]]
[[Space-grant university]] |endowment =US$453 million |chairman = Wm. Andrew Haggard |president = [[Eric J. Barron]] |provost = [[Garnett S. Stokes]] |faculty =2,150{{Cite web| title= Regular Faculty | work=Faculty: Headcount | publisher=Florida State University â Office of Institutional Research | year=2008 | url=http://www.ir.fsu.edu/Faculty_Headcount/facultyheadcount.htm | accessdate=August 29, 2009}} |staff = 6,129{{Cite web| title=Full-Time Employees by Primary Function, Ethnicity and Gender, Fall 2008 | work=2008â09 Factbook (IPEDS â Fall Staff Survey) | publisher=Florida State University â Office of Institutional Research | date=Fall 2008 | url=http://www.ir.fsu.edu/Factbooks/2008-09/Employee_Demographics.pdf | format=PDF | accessdate=August 29, 2009}} |students = 40,838{{Cite web| title=Student Enrollment | work=Student Information | publisher=Florida State University â Office of Institutional Research | date=Fall 2006 to Fall 2010 | url=http://www.ir.fsu.edu/studentinfo.cfm?ID=enroll | accessdate=December 9, 2010}} |undergrad = 31,005 |postgrad = 8,511 |city =[[Tallahassee, Florida|Tallahassee]] |state =Florida |country =United States |campus =Urban area
Main Campus: {{convert|451.6|acre|km2}} ({{convert|1585|acre|km2}} including other properties){{Cite web| title=Fall 2010 Fact Sheet â Campus Size | work=Office of Insitutional Research | publisher=Florida State University | year=2010 | url=http://www.ir.fsu.edu/reports.cfm?cat=campussize&ID=fall2010factsheet | accessdate=January 29, 2011}} |colors =Garnet {{color box|#540115}} and Gold {{color box|#CDC092}} |nickname =[[Florida State Seminoles|Seminoles]] |fightsong =''Fight for FSU'' |website =[http://www.fsu.edu www.fsu.edu] |logo =[[File:FSU logo.png|185px]] }} The '''Florida State University''' (commonly referred to as '''Florida State''' or '''FSU'''){{Cite web| title=2009â2010 General Bulletin | work=Bulletin | publisher=Florida State University â University Registrar | date=2009-2010 | url=http://registrar.fsu.edu/bulletin/undergrad/info/the_university.htm | accessdate=August 29, 2009}} is a [[space-grant]] and [[sea-grant]] [[public university]] located in [[Tallahassee, Florida]], United States. It is a comprehensive [[doctoral]] [[research university]] with medical programs and significant research activity as determined by the [[The Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching|Carnegie Foundation]].{{Cite web| title=Florida State University | work=Classifications | publisher=The Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching | year=2009 | url=http://www.carnegiefoundation.org/classifications/sub.asp?key=748&subkey=13837&start=782 | accessdate=August 29, 2009}} The university comprises 15 separate [[colleges]] and 39 centers, facilities, labs and institutes that offer more than 300 programs of study, including professional programs.{{Cite web| title=Colleges, Schools, Departments, Institutes, and Administrative Units | work=FSU Departments | publisher=Florida State University | date=August 21, 2009 | url=http://www.fsu.edu/departments/#centers | accessdate=August 29, 2009}} Florida State was officially established in 1851 and is located on the oldest continuous site of higher education in the state of Florida. Florida State University was declared in 2010 to be a "Budget Ivy" university by the ''Fiske Guide to Getting into the Right College''.{{cite news |title= Rummaging the Bargain Bin for a Premier Public Education|first=Jacques |last=Steinberg|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date= September 27, 2010 |url=http://thechoice.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/09/27/budget-ivy/?utm_source=twitterfeed&utm_medium=twitter |accessdate=October 20, 2010}} In 1935 Florida State University was awarded the first chapter of [[Phi Beta Kappa]] in Florida and is among the ten percent of American universities to have earned a chapter of the national academic honor society.{{cite web |title= Phi Beta Kappa â About Us |date= March 29, 2011 |url= http://www.pbk.org/infoview/PBK_InfoView.aspx?t=&id=8 |accessdate= March 29, 2011}}{{cite web |title= Phi Beta Kappa â Alpha of Florida |date= March 29, 2011 |url= http://pbk.fsu.edu/ |accessdate= March 29, 2011}} Florida State is a [[flagship#University campuses|flagship university]] in the [[State University System of Florida]].{{Cite web| title=Timeline | work=The Florida Memory Project | publisher=State Library and Archives of Florida | year=1851 | url=http://www.floridamemory.com/exhibits/timeline/index.cfm | accessdate=July 6, 2010}}{{Cite news | last=Specht | first=Mary | last2=DeBarros | first2=Anthony | title=USA TODAY's 2006 College Tuition & Fees Survey | newspaper=USA TODAY | date=September 5, 2006 | url=http://www.usatoday.com/news/education/2006-08-30-tuition-survey_x.htm | accessdate=August 29, 2009}}{{Cite web| last=Berdahl | first=Robert M | authorlink=http://www.aau.edu/about/article.aspx?id=9064 | title=The Future of Flagship Universities | work=Speeches | publisher=University of California, Berkeley | date=October 5, 1998 | url=http://cio.chance.berkeley.edu/chancellor/sp/flagship.htm | accessdate=August 29, 2009}} As one of Florida's primary graduate research universities,{{Cite web| title=PhD Programs | work=Pathways of Excellence | publisher=Florida State University | year=2008 | url=http://pathways.fsu.edu/doctoral/ | accessdate=August 29, 2009 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080210074227/http://pathways.fsu.edu/doctoral/ |archivedate = February 10, 2008}} Florida State University awards over 2,000 graduate and professional [[academic degree|degrees]] each year.{{Cite web| title=Degrees Awarded by College â Annual 2007â08 | work=Degrees Awarded | publisher=Florida State University â Office of Institutional Research | date=2007-2008 | url=http://www.ir.fsu.edu/degreesawarded/degreesawarded.htm | accessdate=August 29, 2009}}{{cite news|url=http://www.floridatoday.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070627/BREAKINGNEWS/70627074/1086 |date=June 27, 2007 |publisher=FloridaToday.com |title=Crist signs differential tuition bill |author=Aaron DeSlatte and Angeline Taylor |accessdate=June 30, 2007 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070930022322/http://www.floridatoday.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070627/BREAKINGNEWS/70627074/1086 |archivedate = September 30, 2007}} In 2007, Florida State was placed in the first tier of research universities by the Florida Legislature, a distinction allowing FSU, along with the University of Florida, to charge 40% higher tuition than other institutions in the State University System of Florida.{{cite press release | title=Wetherell praises Crist's decision on tuition | publisher=Florida State University | date=June 27, 2007 | url=http://www.fsu.edu/news/2007/06/27/tuition.rates/ | accessdate =August 28, 2009}} The Florida State University is also home to nationally ranked programs in many academic areas, including the sciences, engineering, social policy, film, music, theater, dance, visual art, business, political science, psychology, social work, medicine, and law.{{Cite web|url=http://www.fsu.edu/highlights/rankings.html#human/ |title=Florida State University â College Highlights and Selected National Rankings |accessdate=May 1, 2007}} Florida State is home to Florida's only National Laboratory â the [[National High Magnetic Field Laboratory]] and is the birthplace of the commercially-viable anti-cancer drug [[Taxol]]. The Florida State University athletics programs are favorites of passionate students, fans and alumni across the United States, which often appear in conjunction with the [[Marching Chiefs]] of the FSU College of Music. Florida State is a member of the [[Atlantic Coast Conference]] and has won twelve national athletic championships as well as multiple individual competitor NCAA championship awards. ==History== {{Main|History of Florida State University}} {{See also|Presidents of Florida State University}} [[File:WFS rc04562.jpg|thumb|left|West Florida Seminary main building, circa 1880. Built in 1854 as the Florida Institute. This building was replaced with College Hall in 1891. The [[Westcott Building]] now stands on this site â the oldest site of higher education in Florida]] The Florida State University traces its origins to a plan set by the 1823 Territorial Legislature of Florida to create a system of higher education. The 1838 Florida Constitution codified the basic system by providing for land allocated for the schools.{{Cite web|url=http://www.floridamemory.com/Collections/Constitution/1838_index.cfm |title=State Library and Archives of Florida â The Florida Memory Project, Florida Constitution of 1838, Article X â Education |accessdate=May 28, 2007}} In 1851 the Florida Legislature voted to establish two seminaries of higher education on opposite sides of the [[Suwannee River]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.fsu.edu/about/history.html |title=About Florida State â History |publisher=Office of University Communications |date=September 23, 2009 |accessdate=July 11, 2010}} [[Francis W. Eppes]] and other city leaders established an all-male academy called the Florida Institute in Tallahassee as a legislative inducement to locate the '''West Florida Seminary''' in [[Tallahassee]].{{Cite web|url=http://fpc.dos.state.fl.us/reference/rc09230.jpg |title=State Library and Archives of Florida â Florida Photographic Collection'' |accessdate=April 29, 2007}} The [[East Florida Seminary]] opened in [[Ocala, Florida|Ocala]] in 1853, closed in 1861, and reopened in [[Gainesville, Florida|Gainesville]] in 1866.{{Cite web|url=http://fulltext10.fcla.edu/DLData/SN/SN00154113/0055_003/55no3.pdf |title=Book Review: Gone with the Hickory Stick: School Days in Marion County 1845â1960, p.122, The Florida Historical Quarterly â Volume LV, Number 3 January 1977 |accessdate=July 12, 2010}} The East Florida Seminary is the institution to which the modern [[University of Florida]] traces its foundation.{{Cite web| last=Pickard | first=Ben | title=A History of Gainesville, Florida | work=Historic Gainesville, A Tour Guide to the Past | publisher=Historic Gainesville Incorporated | year=1991 | url=http://www.afn.org/~hgi/gnvhistory.html | accessdate=September 1, 2009}}{{Cite web| last=Armstrong | first=Orland Kay | title=The life and work of Dr. A. A. Murphree| date=c. 1928 | pages=40â41| url=http://www.uflib.ufl.edu/ufdc/?m=hdFC&i=76093&td=florida+universit | accessdate=July 22, 2010}} [[File:Denham FSU rc11524.jpg|thumb|right|140px|William Denham, West Florida Seminary cadet during the Civil War]] In 1856, the land and buildings in an area formerly known as [[Gallows]] Hill â where the Florida Institute was built â was accepted as the site of the state seminary for male students. Two years later the institution absorbed the [[Tallahassee Female Academy]] founded in 1843 as the Misses Bates School and became coeducational."Tallahassee Female Academy circa 187-. Archives metadata: A female academy. West Florida Seminary building on Park Avenue between Duval and Bronough Streets, Tallahassee, Florida" {{Cite web|url= http://fpc.dos.state.fl.us/reference/rc01133.jpg | title=State Library and Archives of Florida â Florida Photographic Collection|accessdate=April 29, 2007}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.lib.fsu.edu/dlmc/dlc/files/dlmc/FTaSU2004009.html#biographicalhistorical |title=Florida State University Libraries â John L. DeMilly Papers 1877â1879, Historical Note |accessdate=April 28, 2007 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20060903011211/http://www.lib.fsu.edu/dlmc/dlc/files/dlmc/FTaSU2004009.html#biographicalhistorical |archivedate = September 3, 2006}} The West Florida Seminary stood near the front of the Westcott Building on the existing FSU campus, making this site the oldest continually used location of higher learning in Florida."No. 3 was the seminary. Built in 1854. In use 1857, when classes began, until 1891 when it was remolded to College Hall."
{{Cite web|url=http://fpc.dos.state.fl.us/reference/rc02068.jpg |title=State Library and Archives of Florida â Florida Photographic Collection, Map showing location of the West Florida Seminary published 1885. |accessdate=April 29, 2007}}"Building given to the seminary at its inception (1857) for classes. Destroyed in 1891 to make way for College Hall."
{{Cite web|url=http://fpc.dos.state.fl.us/reference/rc04562.jpg |title=State Library and Archives of Florida â Florida Photographic Collection, West Florida Seminary circa 1884. |accessdate=April 29, 2007}}"Constructed in 1891. Replaced by Westcott in 1909."
{{Cite web|url=http://fpc.dos.state.fl.us/reference/rc00003.jpg |title=State Library and Archives of Florida â Florida Photographic Collection, College Hall at the West Florida Seminary circa 1898. |accessdate=April 29, 2007}} ===Student soldiers=== In 1860â61 the legislature started formal military training at the school with a law amending the original 1851 statute.{{Cite book| last=Coles | first=David J. | title=Florida's Seed Corn: The History of the West Florida Seminary During the Civil War | publisher=Florida Historical Quarterly 77 | year=1999 | page=288 | jstor=30147582}} [[Florida in the American Civil War|During the Civil War]], the seminary became '''The Florida Military and Collegiate Institute.''' Enrollment at the school increased to around 250 students with the school establishing itself as perhaps the largest and most respected educational institution in the state. Cadets from the school defeated [[Union (American Civil War)|Union forces]] at the [[Battle of Natural Bridge]] in 1865, leaving Tallahassee as the only [[Confederate States of America|Confederate]] capital east of the [[Mississippi River]] not to fall to Union forces.{{Cite web|url=http://www.floridamemory.com/Timeline/Timeline/ |title=State Library and Archives of Florida, The Florida Memory Project â Timeline | year=1865 | accessdate=August 26, 2009}}"West Florida Seminary cadets taking a break."
{{Cite web|url=http://fpc.dos.state.fl.us/reference/rc01132.jpg |title=State Library and Archives of Florida â Florida Photographic Collection, West Florida Seminary Cadets, published circa 187-. |accessdate=April 29, 2007}} The students were trained by [[Valentine Mason Johnson]], a graduate of [[Virginia Military Institute]], who was a professor of mathematics and the chief administrator of the college.{{Cite web| last=Pugnale | first =John D | title=Family history â Valentine Mason Johnson | url=http://pugknows.com/valentine_mason_johnson.htm | accessdate=August 28, 2009}} After the fall of the Confederacy, campus buildings were occupied by Union military forces for approximately four months and the West Florida Seminary reverted to its former academic purpose.{{Cite book|title=History of West Florida Seminary |last=Dodd |first=William G. |year=1952 |publisher=Florida State University |location=Tallahassee, Fla. |pages=27â28}} ===First state university=== In February 1883 the West Florida Seminary became part of Florida University, the first state university in Florida.{{Cite book| last=Bush | first=George Gary | title=History of Education in Florida | publisher=Government Printing Office | year=1889 | location=Washington | pages=46â47 | url=http://www.cfmemory.org/cdm4/document.php?CISOROOT=/cfm&CISOPTR=46918|accessdate=July 13, 2010}} Under the new university charter, the seminary became the institution's Literary College, and was to contain several "schools" or departments in different disciplines. However, in the new university association the seminary's "separate Charter and special organization" were maintained.{{Cite book|url=http://books.google.com/?id=OFcpAAAAYAAJ&dq=florida+university&printsec=frontcover&q= |title=Journal of the Proceedings of the Constitutional Convention of the State of Florida, p. 21 |date=June 9, 1885 |publisher=Harvard College Library | accessdate=July 13, 2010|author1=Constitutional Convention, Florida}} Florida University also incorporated the Tallahassee College of Medicine and Surgery, and recognized three more colleges to be established at a later date. The Florida Legislature recognized the university under the title "University of Florida" in Spring 1885, but committed no additional financing or support.{{Cite web| last=Armstrong | first=Orland Kay | title=The Life and Work of Dr. A. A. Murphree, p. 40 | date=c. 1928 | url=http://www.uflib.ufl.edu/ufdc/?m=hdFC&i=76093&td=florida+universit | accessdate=July 13, 2010}} Without legislative support, the university project struggled. The institution never assumed the "university" title, and the association dissolved when the medical college relocated to Jacksonville later that year. However, the act recognizing the Tallahassee institution as the "University of Florida" was not repealed until 1903, when the title was transferred to what had been the [[Florida Agricultural College]]. [[File:Rc01122.jpg|thumb|220px|right|Chemistry lab in 1900]] However, the West Florida Seminary, as it was still generally called, continued to expand and thrive. It shifted its focus towards modern-style post-secondary education, awarding "Licentiates of Instruction", its first diplomas, in 1884, and awarding Bachelor of Arts degrees in 1891. It had become Florida's first [[liberal arts]] college by 1897, and in 1901 it was reorganized into the '''Florida State College''' with four departments (the College, the College Academy, the School for Teachers and the School of Music). The 1905 Buckman Act, named after [[Henry Holland Buckman]], reorganized the Florida college system into a school for [[Caucasian race|white]] males (University of the State of Florida), a school for white females ('''Florida State College for Women'''), and a school for African Americans (Florida Agricultural and Mechanical College for Negroes).{{Cite web|url=http://fpc.dos.state.fl.us/reference/rc05025.jpg |title=State Library and Archives of Florida â Florida Photographic Collection, Westcott Building at the Florida State College for Women, published 193-. |accessdate=April 28, 2007}} By 1933 the Florida State College for Women had grown to be the third largest women's college in the United States and was the first state women's college in the [[Southern United States|South]] to be awarded a chapter of [[Phi Beta Kappa]], as well as the first university in Florida so honored.{{Cite web|url=http://diglib.lib.fsu.edu/findaids/FTaSU2003003.pdf |title=Florida State University Libraries Special Collections Department, Inventory of the Florida State College for Women Surveys and Reports (MSS2003003), Biographical/Historical Notes. |author=Amy McDonald. |publisher=Florida State University Libraries |year=2004 |accessdate=April 30, 2007|format=PDF}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.lib.fsu.edu/dlmc/dlc/files/dlmc/FTaSU2005014.pdf |title=Florida State University Libraries Special Collections Department, Inventory of the Florida State College for Women/Florida State University Phi Beta Kappa Alpha of Florida Chapter. (MSS2005-014) Biographical/Historical Notes. |author=Erin VanClay |publisher=Florida State University Libraries |month=September | year=2005 |accessdate=April 30, 2007|format=PDF |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20060903010622/http://www.lib.fsu.edu/dlmc/dlc/files/dlmc/FTaSU2005014.pdf |archivedate = September 3, 2006}} Florida State was the largest of the original two universities in Florida, even during the period as the college for women (1905 to 1947) until 1919.{{Cite web|url=http://www.flbog.org/resources/_doc/factbooks/quickfacts/200804SUS_Headcount_Enrollment_1905-present.xls |title=Florida Board of Governors SUS Headcount Enrollment â 1905 â present |accessdate=May 18, 2009}} The influx of [[G.I. Bill|G.I. Bill students]] after World War II stressed the state university system to the point that a Tallahassee Branch of the University of Florida (TBUF) was opened on the campus of the Florida State College for Women with the men housed in [[barracks]] on nearby [[Dale Mabry Field]].{{Cite web|url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image:Tbuf_rc01381.jpg |title=State Library and Archives of Florida â Florida Photographic Collection, Tallahassee Branch of the University of Florida at the Florida State College for Women circa 1946 |accessdate=April 30, 2007}} By 1947 the Florida Legislature returned the FSCW to coeducational status and designated it the '''Florida State University'''.{{Cite web|url=http://fsu.edu/news/2007/04/12/norwood.doctorate/ |title=Personal history of Mary Lou Norwood, FSCW/FSU Alumna, (transitional) Class of 1947 (FSU webpage) |accessdate=April 30, 2007}} The FSU West Campus land and barracks plus other areas continually used as an airport later became the location of the [[Tallahassee Community College]]. The post-war years brought substantial growth and development to the university as many departments and colleges were added including Business, Journalism (discontinued in 1959), [[Library Science]], [[Nursing]] and Social Welfare. Strozier Library, Tully Gymnasium and the original parts of the Business building were also built at this time. ===Student activism=== [[File:FSU protest Tallahassee rc01458.jpg|thumb|right|220px|Student protest in Tallahassee â 1970]]During the 1960s and 1970s the Florida State University became a center for [[student activism]] especially in the areas of [[racial integration]], [[women's rights]] and opposition to the [[Vietnam War]]. The school acquired the nickname 'Berkeley of the South'{{Cite web|url=http://www.fsu.edu/news/2006/09/06/remembering.sixties/ |title=Florida State University, News Archive, Events' |accessdate=April 30, 2007}} during this period, in reference to similar student activities at the [[University of California, Berkeley]]. The school is also purported to have originated the 1970s fad of "[[streaking]]", said to have been first observed on Landis Green.{{Cite web|url=http://www.fsu.edu/~fstime/FS-Times/Volume2/apr97web/4apr97.html |title=Streaking an FSU First |publisher=Florida State Times |date=April/May 1997 |accessdate=June 29, 2007}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.tallahasseenaturally.org/students.html |publisher=Tallahassee Naturally, Inc.'' |accessdate=June 29, 2007 |title=Streaking}} After many years as a segregated university, in 1962 Maxwell Courtney became the first African American undergraduate student admitted to Florida State.{{Cite web|url=http://www.fsu.com/pages/2004/01/30/courtney_room.html |title=FSU Black Alumni Association pays tribute to first black student | date=January 30, 2004 | accessdate=April 20, 2008 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20061026214140/http://www.fsu.com/pages/2004/01/30/courtney_room.html |archivedate = October 26, 2006}} In 1968 Calvin Patterson became the first African American player for the Florida State University football team.{{Cite web|url=http://rmfo-blogs.com/hoss/2005/11/16/calvin-patterson/ |title=Walk With Me â Sports Illustrated |date= November 16, 2005 | accessdate=April 20, 2008}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Florida State today has the highest graduation rate for African American students of all universities in Florida.{{Cite web|url=http://www.sptimes.com/2007/11/19/State/More_blacks_succeed_a.shtml |title=More blacks succeed at FSU â St. Petersburg Times November 19, 2007 |accessdate=April 20, 2008}} On March 4, 1969 the FSU chapter of [[Students for a Democratic Society (1960 organization)|Students for a Democratic Society]], an unregistered university student organization, sought to use university facilities for meetings. The FSU administration, under President Stanley Marshall, subsequently decided not to allow the SDS the use of university property and obtained a court injunction to bar the group. The result was a protest and [[mass arrest]] at bayonet point of some 58 students in an incident later called the Night of the Bayonets.{{Cite web|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jkoslow/studentprojects/pubhisfall06website/timeline.html |title=FSU Timeline â Exploring FSU's Past | date=March 4, 1969 | accessdate=August 26, 2009}} The university Faculty Senate later criticized the administration's response as provoking as an artificial crisis.{{Cite web|url=http://www.tampabay.com/google_archive/search.php |publisher=St. Petersburg Times |title=Night of the Long Knives | date=March 6, 1969 | accessdate=August 26, 2009}} Another notable event occurred when FSU students massed in protest of student deaths at [[Kent State University]] causing classes to be canceled.{{Cite web|url=http://www.tampabay.com/google_archive/search.php |publisher=The Evening Independent |title=Universities Close; Kirk Sits All Night on Campus | date=May 8, 1970 | accessdate=August 26, 2009}} Approximately 1000 students marched to the ROTC building where they were confronted by police armed with shotguns and carbines. Joining the all-night vigil, Governor [[Claude Kirk]] appeared unexpectedly with a wicker chair and spent hours, with little escort or fanfare, on Landis Green discussing politics with protesting students. [[File:CFEC 001.jpg|thumb|left|140px|Rally at Westcott, February 13th, 2008]] [[LGBTQ]] activism at FSU is unusual in that it was actually a fight against the school itself. The Pride Student Union (PSU), originally LGBSU, was founded in 1969 to represent LGBTQ students.{{cite web|last=Peralta-Armstrong|first=Jazmin|title=Note on LGBSU Founding Date|url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/tallahassee/access/1956376751.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=Feb+6%2C+2010&author=Jazmin+Peralta-Armstrong&pub=Tallahassee+Democrat&edition=&startpage=n%2Fa&desc=Some+FSU+groups+dread+relocation|publisher=Tallahassee.com|accessdate=11 October 2011}}{{cite web|last=Eberhardt|first=Celeste|title=Florida State U. LGBT union now the Pride Student Union|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-124351407.html|publisher=University Wire|accessdate=11 October 2011}} In 1980 a gay male named William Wade won the title of Homecoming Princess under the pseudonym "Billy Dahling" causing controversy.{{cite web|last=Koslow|first=Jennifer|title=FSU Timeline|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jkoslow/studentprojects/pubhisfall06website/timeline.html|publisher=Florida State University|accessdate=11 October 2011}}{{cite web|title=FSU 'Princess Wouldn't Want a Repeat|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/19777/FSU-PRINCESS-WOULDNT-WANT-A-REPEAT.html|publisher=Deseret News|accessdate=11 October 2011}}{{cite web|last=Hintikka|first=M. B.|title=Severance: Billie Dahhling: Homecoming Princess|url=http://santababylonia.net/breath/dahhling.html|publisher=Gregory Severance|accessdate=11 October 2011}} In 2006 the Union Board added [[sexual orientation]] to its nondiscrimination policy causing several student organizations to be zero-funded for noncompliance. [[Christian Legal Society]] got the senate to reverse the freezing, despite protests, after threatening a lawsuit.{{cite web|title=News Clips of the State University System of Florida February 18, 2008|url=http://www.flbog.org/documents/News%20Clips%202008_02_18.pdf|publisher=Board of Governors|accessdate=11 October 2011}}{{cite web|last=Baylor|first=Greg|title=FSU Reinstates CLS Chapter Funding|url=http://religiousfreedom.blogspot.com/2008/02/fsu-reinstates-cls-chapter-funding.html|publisher=The Center for Law and Religious Freedom|accessdate=11 October 2011}} After that members from several organizations founded The Coalition for an Equitable Community(CFEC) which was devoted to advocating for an inclusive nondiscrimination policy.{{cite web|last=Coalition for an Equitable Community|title=Coation for an Equitable Community on Wayback Machine|url=http://web.archive.org/web/20110207201623/http://fsucoalition.com/|publisher=Wayback Machine|accessdate=11 October 2011}}{{cite web|title=Gays and lesbians seek protection at FSU|url=http://www.flbog.org/documents/News%20Clips%202008_02_14.pdf|publisher=Tallahassee Democrat via Board of Governors|accessdate=11 October 2011}} In 2007 CFEC filed suit with the FSU Supreme Court against the Union Board for failing to uphold their nondiscrimination policy though they ruled they lacked jurisdiction after hearing the case.{{cite web|last=Hillert|first=C.J.|title=Coalition for an Equitable Community v. Union Board|url=http://sga.fsu.edu/Reporter/2008_coalition_for_an_equitable_community_v_union_board.pdf|accessdate=11 October 2011}} In November 2009 CFEC placed an editorial in the FSView to provide perspective on the issue.{{cite web|last=Pinto|first=Jessica|title=Working Towards Policy Change at FSU|url=http://www.youngpeoplefor.org/node/6374|publisher=FSView via Young People For|accessdate=11 October 2011}} In June 2010 the Board of Trustees passed a resolution protecting students based on sexual orientation, gender identity and gender expression.{{cite web|last=Rodriguez|first=Rebecca|title=Board approves non-discriminatory policy change|url=http://www.fsunews.com/article/20100705/FSVIEW/100702031/Board-approves-non-discriminatory-policy-change|publisher=fsunews|accessdate=11 October 2011}} ==Academics== [[File:FSU Westcott.jpg|thumb|right|600px|[[Westcott Building]] â named for university benefactor and Florida Supreme Court Justice [[James D. Westcott, Jr.]]]] The Florida State University aspires to become a top twenty public research university with at least one-third of its PhD programs ranked in the Top-15 nationally.{{Cite web|url=http://www.flbog.edu/about/_doc/strategicplan/StrategicPlan_05-13.pdf |publisher=The Florida Board of Governors |title=Strategic Plan_05-13 â Florida State University, p.17 | date=June 9, 2005 | accessdate=August 26, 2009}} The university owns more than 1,500 acres (6 kmÂ²) and is the home of the [[National High Magnetic Field Laboratory]] among other advanced research facilities. The university continues to develop in its capacity as a leader in Florida graduate research. Other milestones at the university include the first [[ETA10|ETA10-G/8]] [[supercomputer]],[http://ed-thelen.org/comp-hist/super-users-view.html Ed-thelen.org] ''Jeff Bauer â A History of Supercomputing at Florida State University, 1991'' Retrieved on [[April 30|4â30]]-2007. capable of 10.8 [[GFLOPS]] in 1989, remarkable for the time in that it exceeded the existing speed record of the [[Cray-2|Cray-2/8]], located at the [[Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory]] by a substantial leap and the development of the anti-cancer drug [[Taxol]]. ===Undergraduate Honors Program=== The Florida State University Honors Program is a specially designed program for the most accomplished incoming undergraduates. Undergraduates in Honors participate in smaller classes with faculty, including individual research programs or assigned research in the area of the sponsoring faculty member. Admission to Honors is competitive. The FSU Honors Medical and Law early-admission, professional-track programs are designed to facilitate faster access to professional programs for the limited number of students who meet required standards. Honors students are eligible for the Honors residence hall and associated administrative benefits.{{Cite web|url=http://honors.fsu.edu/prospective/main/academics.html |title=FSU Honors Program website | accessdate=December 27, 2007}}{{Cite web|url=http://registrar.fsu.edu/bulletin/undergrad/info/honors.htm |title=Florida State University 2007â2008 General Bulletin Undergraduate Edition â Honors Program | accessdate=December 27, 2007}} ===Limited Access Programs=== A number of undergraduate academic programs at the Florida State University are termed "Limited Access Programs". Limited Access Programs are programs where student demand exceeds available resources. Admission is thus restricted and sometimes extremely competitive. Examples of limited access programs include The [[Florida State University Film School]], the College of Communication and Information, the College of Nursing, most of the majors in the College of Education, several majors in the College of Visual Arts, Theatre and Dance and all majors in the College of Business.{{Cite web|url=http://registrar.fsu.edu/bulletin/undergrad/info/admissions.htm#LimitedAccess |title=FSU 2006â2007 General Bulletin Undergraduate Edition â Limited Access Programs |accessdate=April 30, 2007}} ===Young Scholars Program=== The [[FSU Young Scholars Program]] is a competitive residential science and [[mathematics]] program for 40 Florida [[Secondary education in the United States|high-school students]] with potential for careers in the [[sciences]], engineering, and [[medicine|health professions]].{{cite news|url=http://www.tallahassee.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070620/BREAKINGNEWS/706200317/-1/BREAKINGNEWS |publisher=Tallahassee Democrat |title=Young Scholars Get Ahead at FSU Camp |date=June 20, 2007 |accessdate=June 20, 2007}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}{{Cite web|url=http://bio.fsu.edu/ysp/ |title=Young Scholars Program @ FSU' |accessdate=May 26, 2007}} Admission to the FSU YSP generally requires completing the eleventh grade and scoring at least 90% on a national standardized examination such as the SAT or PSAT. The PSAT Math average is approximately 96% and the PSAT verbal average is approximately 94%. Many students are first in their class at their home schools with 79% being in the top ten of their class.{{Cite web|url=http://bio.fsu.edu/ysp/Program_Description_2009.pdf |title=2009 Young Scholars Program |accessdate=August 26, 2009}} ===Tuition=== Fall 2009 undergraduate tuition costs are [[US$|$]]150.87 dollars per credit hour for in-state tuition while out-of-state tuition is $632.35 dollars per credit hour.{{Cite web|url=http://controller.vpfa.fsu.edu/Student-Financial-Services/SFS-For-Students/Tuition-Fees-Payment/Tuition-Rates-Main-Campus |title=FSU Controller's Office â Tuition Rates â Main Campus |accessdate=August 27, 2009}} Fall 2009 graduate tuition costs are $322.71 dollars per credit hour for in-state tuition, and out-of-state tuition is $954.11 dollars per credit hour. Fall 2009 law school tuition costs are $473.32 dollars per credit hour for in-state tuition, and out-of-state tuition is $1,040.35 dollars per credit hour. Medical School tuition costs are billed per annum. For 2009 FSU College of Medicine costs $18,230.36 dollars a year for in-state tuition, while out-of-state tuition is $52,781.65 dollars. ===Demographics===
'''Fall freshman statistics'''{{Cite web|url=http://www.ir.fsu.edu/Performance_Indicators/Major/Mj01.pdf |title=Office of Institutional Research â FTIC Admitted by Residency Applied, Admitted & Enrolled Fall 1997 through Fall 2009 |accessdate=August 27, 2009}}[http://www.ir.fsu.edu/studentinfo.cfm?ID=sf_admission IR.fsu.edu] {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- !   !! 2010 !! 2009 !! 2008 !! 2007 |- ! Applicants | 20,469 || 18,583 || 20,678 || 20,058 |- ! Admits | 11,746 || 10,669 || 8,736 || 9,634 |- ! % Admitted | 57.4 || 57.41 || 42.24 || 48.03 |} ''This table does not include deferred
applications or other unique situations.''
The middle 50% of the Fall 2010 incoming freshmen class had a [[GPA]] range from 3.6 â 4.1; a [[SAT]] range from 1150â1300 and an [[ACT (examination)|ACT]] range from 25 â 29.{{Cite web| title = Facts for Prospective Students | work=Student Information | publisher=Florida State University | url = http://www.ir.fsu.edu/studentinfo.cfm?ID=sf_admission | accessdate = December 4, 2010}} FSU's freshman retention rate is 91%.{{Cite web| title = Summary Meeting Minutes | work=The Florida State University Board of Trustees Meeting | publisher=The Florida State University Board of Trustees | date = Thursday, September 17, 2009 | url = http://trustees.fsu.edu/meetings/MINUTES-20090917.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate = May 16, 2010}} Florida State has one of the highest retention rates in the United States. The school has a 72% six-year graduation rate compared to the national average six-year graduation rate of 53%.{{Cite web| title = Graduation and Retention Rates | work=Student Information | publisher=Florida State University â Office of Institutional Research | url = http://www.ir.fsu.edu/studentinfo.cfm?ID=sf_gradretention | accessdate = May 16, 2010}}{{Cite web| title=Efforts to Improve Grad Rates Showing Progress | publisher=The University of Texas System | year=2006 | url=http://www.utsystem.edu/news/features/grad_rates_summer07.htm | accessdate=January 7, 2007}} '''[[Rhodes Scholars]]''' In 2008, Florida State undergraduate and football player [[Myron Rolle]] earned the prestigious [[Rhodes Scholarship]] award. Rolle is the fourth FSU student overall to earn this award and the third since 2005. Joe O'Shea, an FSU Student Body President, and [[Garrett Johnson]], an FSU student athlete, earned the award in 2007 and 2005, respectively.{{Cite web|url=http://media.www.fsunews.com/media/storage/paper920/news/2007/11/26/News/Oshea.Earns.Rhodes.Scholarship-3114096.shtml|title=Student body president becomes second FSU Rhodes Scholar in three years|accessdate=November 7, 2007}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.fsu.edu/news/2005/11/21/johnson.rhodes/|title=FSU student-athlete Garrett Johnson wins Rhodes Scholarship|accessdate=July 21, 2005}} Only thirty two students in the United States earn the award each year.{{Cite web|url=http://fsu.edu/indexBOFStory.html?lead.cancer.rolle.rhodes | title=FSU's Myron Rolle named 2009 Rhodes Scholar | accessdate=November 22, 2008}} ===Rankings=== {{Infobox US university ranking | ARWU_W = 151â200 | ARWU_N = 70â89 | USNWR_NU = 101 | Wamo_NU = 108 }} [[File:Dodd Hall FSU.JPG|right|thumb|210px|Dodd Hall]] [[File:College of Law Rotunda.jpg|thumb|right|210px|The D'Alemberte Rotunda, part of the [[Florida State University College of Law|College of Law]], is used to host special events and in the past has been used by the [[Florida Supreme Court]] to convene special sessions]] [[File:FSU MedSchool 0043 (067).jpg|thumb|right|210px|[[Florida State University College of Medicine|College of Medicine]]]] In 2010 Florida State University was included in the "Budget Ivy List" of universities prepared by the ''Fiske Guide to Getting into the Right College''. In 2010 ''[[USA Today]]'' and ''[[The Princeton Review]]'' rated Florida State University as fourth in its list of public "Best Value Colleges".{{cite news|url=http://www.usatoday.com/news/education/best-value-colleges.htm |work=USA TODAY |title=Best Value Colleges for 2010 |accessdate=April 9, 2010 | date=January 12, 2010}} The Florida State University is currently ranked 47th among public universities and 102nd overall in Tier 1 for National Universities by ''[[U.S. News and World Report]]''.{{Cite web|url=http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-colleges/national-universities-rankings/page+5 | publisher=US News |title=Americas Best Colleges |accessdate=August 22, 2009}} In addition |accessdate=April 15, 2007}} 30th among U.S. public universities and 76th among all U.S. universities by ''[[Forbes]]'' magazine,{{Cite web|url=http://www.forbes.com/opinions/forbes/2008/0519/030_4.html |work=Forbes |title=How to choose a college |accessdate=May 14, 2008}} Florida State was ranked 15th nationally in the February 2008 edition of ''[[Kiplinger's Personal Finance|Kiplinger's]]'' ''Best Values in Public Colleges''.{{Cite web|url=http://content.kiplinger.com/tools/colleges/pubcollege.php?sortby=INRANK04&orderby=flip&states%5B%5D=ALL&myschool%5B%5D=none&outputby=table|publisher=Kiplinger.com |title=Best Values in Public Colleges |accessdate=May 1, 2007}} FSU is the second-least-expensive [[flagship#University campuses|flagship university]] in the United States, according to ''[[USA Today]]''. Florida State ranks as the 155th university worldwide and the 79th in the United States in the ''[[Academic Ranking of World Universities]].''{{Cite web| title=Top 100 North & Latin American Universities]] in 2009, Florida State University ranks 43rd university in the United States and Canada and 53rd in the world.{{Cite web| title=Ranking of World Universities â Top USA & Canada | work=Webometrics Ranking of World Universities | publisher=Cybermetrics Lab, Consejo Superior de Investigaciones CientÃ­ficas | date=July 1, 2009 | http://web.archive.org/web/20071022170254/http://fsu.com/pages/2007/03/15/HispanicStudentBeacon.html |archivedate = October 22, 2007}} ===Organization=== As a part of the [[State University System of Florida]], the Florida State University falls under the purview of the [[Florida Board of Governors]]. However, a 13-member [[Board of trustees]] is "vested with the authority to govern and set policy for The Florida State University as necessary to provide proper governance and improvement of the University in accordance with law and rules of the Florida Board of Governors".{{Cite web|url=http://trustees.fsu.edu/org/index.html?procedures |title=FSU Trustees Procedures |accessdate=July 6, 2007 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070622151454/http://trustees.fsu.edu/org/index.html?procedures |archivedate = June 22, 2007}} [[Eric J. Barron|Dr. Eric Barron]] was appointed president in 2009, succeeding [[T. K. Wetherell|Dr. T. K. Wetherell]], and is responsible for day-to-day operation and administration of the university. Both Dr. Barron and Dr. Wetherell are FSU graduates. The Florida State University offers Associate, Bachelor, Masters, Specialist, Doctoral, and Professional degree programs through its sixteen colleges. The most popular Colleges by enrollment are Arts and Sciences, Business, Social Sciences, Education, and Human Science.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ir.fsu.edu/Factbooks/2006-07/Headcount_Schools.pdf |title=Headcount Summaries by School/College, Fall Semesters |accessdate=July 6, 2007|format=PDF}} Florida State University â Office of Institutional Research The [[Florida State University College of Medicine]] operates using diversified hospital and community-based clinical education medical training for [[medical students]]. Founded on the mission to provide care to medically under served populations, the Florida State University College of Medicine for patient-centered care. The students spend their first two years taking basic science courses on the FSU campus in Tallahassee and are then assigned to one of the regional medical school campuses for their third- and fourth-year clinical training. Rotations can be done at one of the six regional campuses in [[Daytona Beach, FL|Daytona Beach]], [[Fort Pierce, FL|Fort Pierce]], [[Orlando, FL|Orlando]], [[Pensacola, FL|Pensacola]], [[Sarasota, FL|Sarasota]] or stay in Tallahassee if they so choose.{{Cite web|url=http://med.fsu.edu/AboutCOM/default.asp |publisher=Florida State University College of Medicine |title= About the College |accessdate=May 11, 2007 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070422232140/http://med.fsu.edu/AboutCOM/default.asp |archivedate = April 22, 2007}} ====FSU Foundation and Seminole Boosters==== The Florida State University receives, in addition to state funding, financial support from The Florida State University Foundation, an organization which exists solely to manage gifts and donations to the university.{{Cite web|url=http://foundation.fsu.edu/community/Page.aspx?pid=777 |title=Florida State University Foundation â Frequently Asked Questions |accessdate=August 28, 2009}} The Foundation manages the university's [[College endowment|endowment]], currently amounting to well over half a billion dollars.{{Cite web| title=NES Public Table â All Institutions By Market Value â Fiscal Year 2010 | work=2010 NACUBO Endowment Study | publisher=National Association of College and University Business Officers | year=2011 | url=http://www.nacubo.org/Documents/research/2010NCSE_Public_Tables_Endowment_Market_Values_Final.pdf | format=PDF | accessdate=January 29, 2011}} The endowment helps provide scholarships{{Cite web|url=http://foundation.fsu.edu/community/Page.aspx?pid=911 |title=Florida State University Foundation â Impact on Students |accessdate=August 28, 2009}} to students of the university, support for long-term university goals and for other specific purposes as designated by the various donors. The Seminole Boosters, Inc. is a fund raising organization for university athletics.{{Cite web|url=http://seminole-boosters.fsu.edu/community/Page.aspx?pid=1546 |title=Florida State University Seminole Boosters â Who We Are and What We Do |accessdate=August 28, 2009}} ===Colleges of Florida State University=== {| class="toccolours" style="margin-right: 1em; font-size: 95%; line-height: 1.8em;" width="300px" |- | '''College''' || '''Year founded''' |- | colspan="4" |
